verses.text: Then all the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, "Look, we are your bone and flesh."
verses.comment: Phrase 'bone and flesh' means familial relationship and kinship.

verses.text: Even in times past, when Saul was king over us, it was you who led Israel out and brought them in. And the LORD said to you, 'You will shepherd my people Israel, and you will be ruler over Israel.'
verses.comment: Refers to David's leadership in battle and God's appointment.

verses.text: So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron. King David made a covenant with them at Hebron before the LORD, and they anointed David as king over Israel.
verses.comment: David officially made king over all Israel.

verses.text: David was thirty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years.
verses.comment: Age and total reign duration are specified.

verses.text: He reigned over Judah in Hebron for seven years and six months, and he reigned over all Israel and Judah in Jerusalem for thirty-three years.
verses.comment: Division between reign over Judah and total reign.

verses.text: The king and his men went to Jerusalem against the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land, who spoke to David, saying, "You will not come in here; the blind and the lame will turn you away," thinking, "David cannot come in here."
verses.comment: Jebusites challenge David's ability to conquer Jerusalem.

verses.text: Nevertheless, David captured the stronghold of Zion, that is, the city of David.
verses.comment: Zion becomes the city of David: Jerusalem.

verses.text: David said on that day, "Whoever attacks the Jebusites, let him get up the water shaft to reach the lame and the blind, who are hated by David's soul." Therefore it is said, "The blind and the lame will not enter the house."
verses.comment: Quotation reflects David's mockery of the Jebusite taunt.

verses.text: So David lived in the stronghold and called it the city of David. And David built all around from the Millo and inward.
verses.comment: Millo possibly refers to a rampart or earthwork in Jerusalem.

verses.text: David became greater and greater, for the LORD, the God of hosts, was with him.
verses.comment: Emphasizes divine blessing and growth of David's power.

verses.text: Hiram king of Tyre sent messengers to David, as well as cedar trees, carpenters, and masons, and they built David a house.
verses.comment: Hiram's gifts connect David's kingdom with Gentiles and trade.

verses.text: David knew that the LORD had established him as king over Israel and had exalted his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.
verses.comment: Theological note: David recognizes God's purpose and covenant.

verses.text: David took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem, after he came from Hebron, and more sons and daughters were born to David.
verses.comment: Polygamy common for ancient Near Eastern kings; not endorsed scripturally.

verses.text: These are the names of those born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
verses.comment: First four sons listed: notable for inclusion of Solomon.

verses.text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
verses.comment: Continuation of list of sons born in Jerusalem.

verses.text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
verses.comment: Full list of sons as recorded (names may vary slightly between texts).

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, all the Philistines went up to search for David. But David heard about it and went down to the stronghold.
verses.comment: David prepares for military threat; 'stronghold' likely refers to fortress in Jerusalem.

verses.text: Now the Philistines had come and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.comment: Valley of Rephaim is southwest of Jerusalem.

verses.text: David inquired of the LORD, saying, "Should I go up against the Philistines? Will you deliver them into my hand?" The LORD said to David, "Go up, for I will certainly deliver the Philistines into your hand."
verses.comment: David seeks God's guidance before battle, showing dependence on God.

verses.text: So David came to Baal-perazim, and David defeated them there and said, "The LORD has broken through my enemies before me, like the breakthrough of waters." Therefore he called that place Baal-perazim.
verses.comment: Baal-perazim means 'Lord of breakthroughs'; name commemorates victory.

verses.text: And the Philistines left their idols there, and David and his men carried them away.
verses.comment: David removes Philistine idols; some texts say 'burned.'

verses.text: And the Philistines came up again and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.comment: Second Philistine campaign in the same valley.

verses.text: And when David inquired of the LORD, he said, "You shall not go up; go around to their rear, and come against them opposite the balsam trees."
verses.comment: God gives David a new strategy rather than a frontal assault.

verses.text: And when you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, move quickly. For then the LORD has gone out before you to strike the army of the Philistines.
verses.comment: The sound is a sign of God's supernatural intervention.

verses.text: And David did as the LORD commanded him, and struck down the Philistines from Geba as far as Gezer.
verses.comment: David's obedience and complete victory over the Philistines.
